items.title: The Greek tragedy of Oedipus' daughter - Stephen Esposito
items.author: TED-Ed
items.content:
<article>Get to know the story of Antigone, daughter of Oedipus, who was determined to give her slain brother Polyneices a proper burial.

--

The gods watched as Oedipus‚Äô daughter, Antigone, stole out of the palace in Thebes the morning after a devastating battle. Antigone was on a dangerous mission to do what she felt was right, though it meant risking her life. She sought to abide by divine law and honor her late brother Polyneices through burial‚Äî but the king had other plans. Stephen Esposito shares the tragic Greek tale of Antigone.

<article>FRONTLINE traces Israeli Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu‚Äôs long campaign to destroy Iran‚Äôs nuclear capabilities and counter its proxy forces, the conflict with the Palestinians, and the role of the U.S. through decades of difficulty in the region.

This journalism is made possible by viewers like you. Support your local PBS station here: https://www.pbs.org/donate
 
Drawing on new, insider interviews, this two-hour special examines how long-running and escalating tensions between Israel and Iran erupted into all-out war in June 2025. The film also explores how multiple U.S. presidents have tried to manage the volatile issues at play.

items.title: Let's Kill You a Billion Times to Make You Immortal
items.author: Kurzgesagt ‚Äì In a Nutshell
items.content:
<article>Go to https://ground.news/KiN to get 40% off unlimited access to Ground News so you can compare coverage and think critically about the news you read.

Sources & further reading:
https://sites.google.com/view/sources-quantum-immortality/

No matter how likely your death is, there will always be a version of you that survives. At least according to one of the most bizarre interpretations of quantum mechanics, known as Quantum Immortality.

items.title: Spartan Defeat: Ancient Historian Exposes The Brutal Truth
items.author: History Hit
items.content:
<article>The pass of Thermopylae, 480 BC. 7,000 Spartans and Greeks stood against hundreds of thousands of Persians. They were all killed but became legends; symbols of defiance, bravery and sacrifice. Greek warfare expert Roel Konijnendijk talks through the battle of Thermopylae and separates the facts from fiction. Who was Leonidas? Were there only 300 Spartans? Were they betrayed? Let's find out in this new video.

items.author: Astrum
items.content:
<article>A new visitor from beyond our solar system is hurtling towards us. Larger and older than ‚ÄòOumuamua, it's unlike anything we've seen before. This massive, fast-moving comet, named 3I/ATLAS, is the third interstellar object ever detected and promises to reveal new secrets about the cosmos. In this video, we explore what makes this celestial traveler so unique and what mysteries it might unlock as it makes its close approach to the Sun.

items.title: What if humans went extinct next Friday? | The Gray Area
items.author: Vox
items.content:
<article>What comes after the human?

We‚Äôre living through multiple crises ‚Äî ecological, technological, political. But beneath all of that is something even deeper: a crisis of the self. Who are we, really? How did we come to see ourselves as separate from the world, from each other, from the systems that sustain us? And what if that way of thinking is what got us into this mess?

Today‚Äôs guest is Mark C. Taylor, philosopher, cultural critic, and author of After the Human. Mark and Sean discuss the philosophical roots of climate change, the dangers of individualism, the false promise of techno-utopianism, and what it might mean to shift from seeing ourselves as isolated egos to members of a vast, interdependent web. They talk about AI, death, Hegel, Descartes, hope, and why ideas matter.

Jeffrey Epstein was a college dropout with no formal financial training who amassed a fortune worth hundreds of millions of dollars and mingled with presidents and billionaires. Drawing on court records and media investigations we trace where Epstein's money came from and what happened to it? From his first job as a high school teacher to involvement in a Ponzi scheme, secretive offshore firms, and powerful clients like Les Wexner and Leon Black. items.title: What Trump‚Äôs Fight With Harvard Is Really About
items.author: Bloomberg Originals
items.content:
<article>The Trump administration is escalating its fight with Harvard, pulling multiple levers to pressure America‚Äôs oldest and richest university to comply with its demands. Framing his actions in part as an initiative to fight antisemitism, President Donald Trump has been targeting diversity, equity and inclusion as well as educational independence at Harvard and universities across the country.  Trump has threatened Harvard‚Äôs nonprofit tax status and accreditation, frozen more than $2.6 billion in research funding and moved to cancel about $100 million worth of its federal contracts. He is also trying to bar Harvard from enrolling international students, a key source of revenue. Harvard has been fighting back in court on all fronts. But how long can it resist pressure from Trump?

items.title: We Explored The Only Roman Lighthouse In Britain
items.author: History Hit
items.content:
<article>Try Opera browser FOR FREE here https://opr.as/08-Opera-browser-historyhit

History Hit‚Äôs Tristan Hughes visits the Channel coast in Kent to learn about two key gateways into Roman Britain. First, he visits Dover Castle with Dr Simon Elliott to see the striking remains of the Pharos, one of the best preserved Roman lighthouses in the world. He then visits an exciting excavation 15 miles west at Lympne, where Simon, fellow archaeologist Dr Richard Taylor and their team believe they‚Äôve located another key port that linked Roman Britain to the continent.

This video shines light on the importance of the English Channel to the Romans. It was the vital waterway that connected Britannia with the rest of the Empire. Serviced by ports, forts and lighthouses, vital to the success of Roman Britain

items.title: What your poop can tell you about your health - Hannibal Person
items.author: TED-Ed
items.content:
<article>Travel into the digestive system to see how food is turned into waste, and what causes the different colors and textures of poop.

--

The average person poops out approximately 11,030 kilograms of cumulative waste in a lifetime. That‚Äôs the equivalent of more than 6 SUVs. Oftentimes, that poop is brown. Why is that, considering all the comestibles one consumes? And what‚Äôs going on when poop appears in different colors and textures? Hannibal Person explains the colorful choreography going on inside your bowels.

items.title: Why children get so many vaccines
items.author: Vox
items.content:
<article>Children get a lot of shots in the first few years of life. Here‚Äôs why.

For decades parents and pediatricians have followed the CDC‚Äôs Childhood Immunization Schedule. It‚Äôs a monthly schedule that lays out the age a child should be vaccinated for common infectious diseases. Its main goal is to protect one of our most vulnerable populations: children, especially those under the age of one, and it‚Äôs been wildly successful at doing just that. Diseases like polio or measles that at one time left children paralyzed, brain damaged, or even dead were eliminated in the United States. 

In recent years, more and more parents are choosing to delay or even outright omit parts of this schedule and to be fair‚Ä¶ It IS a very overwhelming thing. Why do young children need so many shots so quickly? 

Support our work. Become a Vox Member today: http://www.vox.com/memberships
